prompt: Facts: Incident occurred on the intervening night of 2nd and 3rd May 1992 in Village Banskheda, Madhya Pradesh.; Accused-respondent Babulal allegedly went to the house of the deceased Ram Prasad and called him out.; Babulal allegedly took Ram Prasad towards the river.; Accused Babulal allegedly assaulted Ram Prasad with a 'lathi' (stick/cudgel) causing injuries.; Injured Ram Prasad returned home and narrated the incident to his wife Dhulibai (PW4), Mohanlal (PW2), and Chhaganlal (PW3), stating that Babulal had assaulted him.; Mohanlal (PW2) lodged the First Information Report (FIR) based on the deceased's narration.; Ram Prasad was taken for medical treatment but succumbed to his injuries.; Post-mortem examination conducted by Dr. R.C. Verma (PW1) revealed head injuries, including a fracture of the parietal bone, consistent with assault by a hard and blunt object, leading to death.; A 'lathi' was allegedly recovered at the instance of the accused Babulal.; The Trial Court (Sessions Judge, Rajgarh) convicted Babulal under Section 302 IPC and sentenced him to life imprisonment.; The High Court of Madhya Pradesh, on appeal, acquitted Babulal, primarily doubting the veracity of the oral dying declaration and the credibility of witnesses PW2, PW3, and PW4.; The State of Madhya Pradesh filed an appeal against the High Court's acquittal order before the Supreme Court. | IPC: Section 302 (Punishment for Murder), Section 300 (Murder - Definition, used implicitly for conviction under 302), Section 304 Part I/II (Culpable homicide not amounting to murder - Considered as alternative, although conviction was under 302)
completion: {"prosecution": [{"argument": "The High Court erred in acquitting the accused by discarding the reliable and consistent oral dying declaration made by the deceased.", "precedents": ["Khushal Rao v. State of Bombay (AIR 1958 SC 22)", "State of U.P. v. Ram Sagar Yadav (1985) 1 SCC 552", "Laxman v. State of Maharashtra (2002) 6 SCC 710"]}, {"argument": "The High Court's decision was perverse as it ignored compelling evidence and drew incorrect inferences, justifying interference by the Supreme Court.", "precedents": ["Chandrappa v. State of Karnataka (2007) 4 SCC 415", "State of U.P. v. Banne @ Baijnath (2009) 4 SCC 271", "Ghurey Lal v. State of U.P. (2008) 10 SCC 450"]}, {"argument": "The medical evidence (post-mortem report by PW1) fully corroborates the ocular testimony and the dying declaration regarding the nature of weapon (lathi) and injuries causing death.", "precedents": ["Solanki Chimanbhai Ukabhai v. State of Gujarat (AIR 1983 SC 484)", "State of U.P. v. Krishna Gopal (AIR 1988 SC 2154)", "Malleshi v. State of Karnataka (2004) 8 SCC 95"]}], "defense": [{"argument": "The High Court correctly acquitted as the prosecution failed to prove its case beyond reasonable doubt; the dying declaration was unreliable and witnesses were interested.", "precedents": ["Kali Ram v. State of H.P. (1973) 2 SCC 808 - Burden of proof always on prosecution.", "Sharad Birdhichand Sarda v. State of Maharashtra (1984) 4 SCC 116 - Principles for circumstantial evidence (though this case involves direct evidence via dying declaration).", "Kake Singh v. State of M.P. (AIR 1982 SC 1021) - Doubts regarding dying declaration benefit the accused."]}, {"argument": "Appellate courts should exercise caution while interfering with an order of acquittal; the High Court's view was a plausible one based on perceived inconsistencies.", "precedents": ["Mrinal Das v. State of Tripura (2011) 9 SCC 479", "Balak Ram v. State of U.P. (1975) 3 SCC 219", "Antar Singh v. State of M.P. (2004) 10 SCC 605"]}, {"argument": "Recovery of the 'lathi' is doubtful and does not conclusively link the accused to the crime.", "precedents": ["Mohd. Aman v. State of Rajasthan (1997) 10 SCC 44 - Weakness in recovery evidence.", "Dudh Nath Pandey v. State of U.P. (1981) 2 SCC 166 - Recovery must be credible and free from doubt.", "Pulukuri Kottaya v. Emperor (AIR 1947 PC 67) - Strict interpretation of Section 27, Evidence Act."]}]}
